column3: was one of the many sites where Canadian and British prisoners of war
column4: nominally attached to Stalag VIIIB/344 Lamsdorf (Lambinowice) had to work for their German captors. There were more than 600 such working parties belonging to Stlag VIII-B/344 in this region. In January 1945
column5: as the Soviet armies resumed their offensive and advanced into Germany
column6: the prisoners based in Pyskowice were marched westward in the so-called Long March or Death March. Some died from the bitter cold and exhaustion. Eventually the survivors were liberated by American troops in April or May 1945.
